header.name: chaos/preprocessor/algorithm/filter.h
header.author: Paul Mensonides
header.overview: The header defines an algorithm that filters elements from a according to a user-specified criteria.

macro.abstract: The macro filters elements from its second argument according to the criteria specified by its first argument.

macro.para: The macro itself expands to a in terms of (s). This , when invoked by , expands to a of the same type as g that contains the elements for which the predicate expands to 1.

The predicate is invoked for each element in g with the current (s), the current element (elem), and, if it exists, the auxiliary data (data or __VA_ARGS__). This invocation must expand to 0, 1, or a in terms of (s) that expands to either 0 or 1. Expansion to a allows the predicate to recurse on itself if necessary.

In C99, it is possible to omit the auxiliary data argument altogether. This is different than passing "nothing" as the auxiliary data.
#define D () (a, b, c)
( (PRED, D,) // #1 (PRED, D) // #2 )
The first line passes "nothing" as the auxiliary data, which causes PRED to be invoked as (e.g.)... PRED(s, a,) The second line omits the auxiliary data, which causes PRED to be invoked as (e.g.)... PRED(s, a) The fundamental difference is that, in the first line, the auxiliary data is empty (which might have a valid meaning as data), but, in the second line, there is no auxiliary data. Hence, the algorithm is overloaded on a .
Invocations of the predicate are trampolined such that each invocation is invoked with (s), where s is the original at the beginning of the algorithm (i.e. ()). This maximizes the utility of the .

Ignoring the complexity of pred (which is invoked once for each element in g), the running time of can be described in terms of the number of required to complete the algorithm. The asymptotic upper and lower bounds are Θ(n+1), where n is the number of elements in g.
